Project MUSE Journals Volume 16, Number 2, April 2009 A Preface to Futurism (on the 100 year anniversary of the publication of the Foundation and Manifesto of Futurism)

Volume 16, Number 2, April 2009

E-ISSN: 1080-6601 Print ISSN: 1071-6068

DOI: 10.1353/mod.0.0098

A Preface to Futurism (on the 100 year anniversary of the publication of the Foundation and Manifesto of Futurism)
Jeffrey T. Schnapp

When the founding manifesto of Futurism first appeared in the Saturday, February 20, 1909 edition of Le ro, a brief preamble was tacked on by Gaston Calmette, the managing editor:

Mr. Marinetti, the young Italian and French poet endowed with a remarkable and fiery talent [1], known throughout the Latin world thanks to his stirring performances [2] and followed by a constellation of enthusiastic disciples [3], has just founded the School of "Futurism" [4], the boldness of whose theories exceeds that of all prior and contemporary schools [5]. The ro has provided a platform for many of the latter [6] (and not the least outstanding among them). So, today, it presents its readers with the manifesto of the "Futurists" [7]. Needless to say, the manifesto's author assumes full responsibility for his singularly daring and extravagant ideas [8] and for their often unjust attack on eminently respectable and universally respected things [9]. Yet it seemed worthwhile to grant our readers an exclusive first look [10] at this document, irrespective of one's views regarding its merits [11].1

Properly speaking, the moment of Futurism's birth had occured four months earlier, when the following article appeared in Corriere della Sera:

This morning, a bit before noon, F. T. Marinetti was heading down Via Domodossola in his car. The vehicle's owner was at the wheel accompanied by a 23 year-old mechanic, Ettore Angelini. Although the details of the incident remain sketchy, it appears that an evasive maneuver was required by the sudden appearance of a bicyclist, and resulted in the vehicle being flipped into a ditch.2

Within a few short weeks the event had been reworked as the foundation myth of the century's first cultural political avant-garde, initially literary but soon encompassing the full spectrum of the arts, whose eleven-point platform weds advocacy of "the habit of energy and fearlessness," "aggressive movement, feverish insomnia, the race pace, the mortal leap, the slap and the punch" to the exaltation of the beauty of speed. The prose is telegraphic, the message time-sensitive; the manifesto is news from the future. Marinetti sought to publish it immediately (and there were leaks and pre-releases). But the news pipeline was so clogged with reports on the simmering Bosnian crisis, soon to be followed by the Messina earthquake, that three months would pass before backstage lobbying by a family friend led to the text's appearance on the Parisian newspaper's front page.

As the artfully crafted prose of the preface reproduced above suggests, the three month delay may also have been motivated by other considerations. Authored by Calmette, Le ro's managing editor since 1903 and the older brother of the noted bacteriologist Albert Calmette, it was strategically placed before the manifesto in order to vaccinate the newspaper's readership against Marinetti's breach of the then-conventional decorum governing cultural debates. Such prefaces were infrequent even in a daily that courted controversy as recently as the Dreyfus affair, carrying no less than four of Émilie Zola's fiery polemics in the run up to the publication of his no less incendiary J'accuse on the pages of its republican socialist rival L'Aurore.3 Though omitted from subsequent editions of the Foundation and Manifesto of Futurism, Calmette's preface marks the inaugural moment in the reception history of the 20th century's first avant-garde.

The commentary that follows tracks Calmette's attempts to comfort and contain even as he acknowledges the manifesto's disruptiveness. The tone is self-assured. The aim is to push Futurism back into the mold of prior literary-artistic schools: to frame its rhetoric of rupture, however incendiary, in a manner that conveys continuity. Yet, in so doing, Calmette cannot resist the temptation to traffic in two of the mainstays of the emerging public sphere of the early 20th century: sensationalism and the claim that this is a Le ro exclusive. Five years later, the editor himself would fall victim to one of the era's most sensational crimes when he was murdered by Henriette Caillaux, wife of the French Minister of Finance, Joseph Caillaux, who had been under attack by the paper.

The French original follows, accompanied by a brief commentary.

M. Marinetti, le jeune poète italien et français, au talent remarquable et fougueux [1], que de retentissantes manifestations ont fait connaître dans tous les pays latins [2], suivi d'une pléiade d'enthousiastes disciples [3], vient de fonder l'Ecole du "Futurisme" [4] dont les théories dépassent en hardiesse toutes celles des écoles antérieures ou contemporaines [5]. Le ro qui a déjà servi de tribune à plusieurs d'entre elles [6], et non des moindres, offre aujourd'hui à ses lecteurs le manifeste des "Futuristes" [7]. Est-il besoin de dire que nous laissons au signataire toute la responsabilité de ses idées singulièrement audacieuses et d'une outrance [8] souvent injuste pour des choses éminemment respectables et, heureusement, partout respectées [9]? Mais il était interessant de réserver à nos lecteurs la primeur [10] de cette manifestation, quel que soit le jugement qu'on porte sur elle [11].


Click for larger view

Gaston Calmette

[1] Thirty-two years old at the time of the manifesto's publication, Marinetti's reputation as a "remarkable and fiery" poet in his pre-Futurist period was based upon the dramatic flair demonstrated in his public readings of hyperlyrical symbolist works such as La Conquête des étoiles—Poème épique (Paris: Éditions de "La Plume," May 1902), La Momie sanglante (Milan: Édition du Journal "Verde e Azzurro," Jan. 1904), Destruction—Poèmes lyriques (Paris: Librarie Léon Vanier, 1904), and La Ville charnelle (Paris: Edward Sansot et Compagnie, July 1908), all written and published in French. Many of these works contained dialogical poems, including so-called petits drames de lumières ("short dramas of light"). Marinetti's play, Le Roi Bombance—Tragédie satirique (Paris: Societé du Mercure de France, June 1905), remained unperformed at the time. The poet had experimented with musical stagings of early poems such as Carillon de Nöel as early as 1907, of which there exist several period recordings (sung by Laura del Lungo and Elisa Petri, always with piano accompaniment).

[2] The "stirring performances" in the Latin world surely included the poetic declamations alluded to above, but the word retentissante emphasizes noise, which suggests that Calmette had a more recent clamor in mind: that which accompanied the January 15, 1909 debut of La donna è mobile (Poupées Électriques) at Turin's Teatro Alfieri, performed by the Compagnia Drammatica di Spettacoli Storici e Popolari "Città di Milano." Reacting to the audience's whistling, Marinetti appeared on stage at the end of the second act, deliberately provoking an upheaval in the auditorium. The resulting uproar made the front page of Le ro:

Un geste d'audace vient de valoir à F. T. Marinetti les honneurs de la caricature dans les principaux organes humoristiques d'Italie. Comme il advint souvent à son illustre compatriote d'Annunzio, Marinetti n'a pas eu le don d'être compris du public devant lequel se représentait pour la première fois à Turin sa pièce Souvent femme varie. Ce n'est pas impunément, en effet, qu'un talent aristocratique comme celui du poète de La Conquête des etoiles en appelle aux intelligences médiocres. On le lui fit bien voir. Dès les premières scènes, les sifflets et les bruits les plus invraisemblables saluèrent l'oeuvre nouvelle. Les partisans de Marinetti ripostèrent par leur enthousiasme. Il y eut des bagarres et des corps à corps, si bien que l'auteur, poussé à bout, parut soudain à la rampe pour exprimer son mépris à la foule hurlante. Ce geste crâne fut aussitôt le motif de nouvelles querelles parmi les spectateurs; des pugilats s'en-suivirent, si bien que par mesure d'ordre public, la pièce fut interrompue à Turin; mais aussitôt trois nouvelles compagnies ont demandé à l'auteur l'autorisation de la monter, ce qui prouve qu'un beau four est parfois plus glorieux et plus profitable qu'un succès médiocre.

(Le ro, Feb. 1, 1909)

[A courageous gesture just earned F. T. Marinetti the honor of being caricatured in Italy's main satirical reviews. As happened often to his illustrious compatriot d'Annunzio, Marinetti proved unable to win over the audience assembled for the Turin premiere of his play La donna è mobile. It is not with impunity that an aristocratic talent like that possessed by the poet of La Conquête des étoiles reaches out to appeal to mediocre intellects. The result was plain to see. Whistling and unimaginable noises greeted the play right from the opening scene. Marinetti's defenders responded with enthusiasm. Tussles and shoving matches broke out, so much so that the author, pushed beyond the pale, suddenly appeared on stage in order to express his contempt for the screaming mob. This brave gesture prompted renewed conflict among the spectators and fistts rerupted: so much so that the forces of order interrupted the Turin performance. But, as soon as this was done, three new theater companies asked for permission to stage the play, proving that a boiling cauldron is sometimes a greater source of glory and gain than a modest success.]

The reference to the enthusiasm of Marinetti's partisans is, of course, echoed less than three weeks later in Calmette's preface to the founding manifesto where he describes the poet's disciples as enthousiastes.

[3] Calmette's choice of the term pléiade is polyvalent. The word alludes to a cluster of six—or, to follow ancient astronomers, seven—stars found in the constellation Taurus: stars that become identified with the seven Alexandrian poets and tragedians who would serve, in turn, as models for two classical revivals—the Toulouse Pléiade of the 14th century and the Renaissance Pléiade of the 16th century, formed by Pierre de Ronsard, Joachim du Bellay, and Jean-Antoine de Baïfe, whose "manifesto" was Du Bellay's La Défense et illustration de la langue française . Accordingly, in 1886, Rodolphe Darzen selected La Pléiade as the title for his Symbolist review, the immediate predecessor to Mercure de France. In all of these cases, the implications are clear and intended as reassuring: despite the manifesto's identification of the we who speaks not only with incendiary poets but also with "large crowds agitated by labor," "the destructive gesture of anarchists," and "the polyphonic tides of modern revolution," Marinetti's disciples will remain a small, aristocratic cohort, not an avant-garde with aspirations to reach out to the working masses. Futurism may not be classicizing like the pléiade of Du Bellay, Calmette suggests, but it will prove but another school in a long lineage of literary currents. The Futurists may hurl their defiance at the stars, but they will remain within the known contours of the galaxy of literary history.

[4] Nowhere in the Futurist manifesto's text is there any indication that the concept of the literary school, a defining feature of the French 19th-century literary scene, remains the appropriate vehicle for the revolution propounded by Marinetti. But Calmette is deliberate in his presentation of Futurism as yet another school: a school cast in the familiar mold of predecessors as Parnassianism, Symbolism, or Naturalism. His reading finds support in the manifesto to the degree that it repeatedly asserts that Futurism is a movement of poets (the turn towards painting, sculpture, music, and architecture would come soon thereafter).

[5] The key distinguishing adjective is hardiesse, derived from the same root as the English hardness, with insinuations of both insolence and novelty. The emphasis is tonal. Jean Moreas's Le Symbolisme, published on September 18, 1886 in Le ro's literary supplement, was anything but hardi. It begins: "Like all the arts, literature evolves: a cyclical evolution with strictly regulated cycles that are complicated by the changes imposed by the march of time and cahnges in context. It would be superfluous to note that each new evolutionary stage corresponds with precision to old age, to the inexorable decline of the immediately preceding school. [...] A new expression of art was thus expected, necessary, inevitable." For Moreas, there was no need to rush into the next century.

[6]Le ro had indeed hosted the leading res of 19th- and early 20th-century French literature, counting among its contributors, Gerard de Nerval, George Sand, Charles Nodier, Guy de Maupassant, Théophile Gauthier, Émile Zola, and Marcel Proust (who dedicated the lead volume of À la Recherche du temps perdu to Calmette). It was identified in particular with Naturalism and Symbolism, having commissioned Moreas ("one of the most visible of these literary revolutionaries") to formulate "the fundamental principles of this new expression of art" (Le ro, Supplement Littéraire, Sept. 18, 1886).

[7] The word "manifesto" generally bore political connotations when employed by the newspaper, though Moreas's Le Symbolisme was indeed presented under the editorial title un manifeste littéraire (albeit on the second page of Le ro's weekly literary supplement, whereas the Futurist manifesto appeared on the front page of the actual issue). Among the other literary manifestos associated with Le ro was the Manifeste des Cinq (Le ro, Aug. 18, 1887), signed by Paul Bonnetain, J.-H. Rosny, Lucien Descaves, Paul Margueritte, and Gustave Guiches, a group of young naturalists disgruntled with Émile Zola (another Le ro contributor). This so-called manifesto, however, was published under the title La Terre, in keeping with the title of the Zola novel that was being invoked as proof of the naturalist master's inexorable artistic decline.


Click for larger view

[8] The key word in this section of Calmette's preface is outrance: a literal transgression of boundaries, a going beyond that which is reasonable or licit, always with a hint of immorality, as in the juridical phrase outrance aux bonnes moeurs (the violation of public morality). This was the standard crime of which licentious writers were accused during the period (among them Barbey d'Aurevilly and Flaubert).

[9] The "eminently respectable and universally respected things" that the founding manifesto of Futurism heaps scorn upon, thereby eliciting Calmette's disapproval, were most likely the museums, libraries, and academies whose destruction was called for in point ten of the manifesto and reprised in its concluding pages. Le ro surely had little use for Marinetti's celebration in point nine of "the destructive gesture of anarchists," given its rightward leanings –it had opposed the 1871 Paris Comune—its sympathies for positivism, and belief in progress. N.B. the phrase in the Foundation and Manifesto of Futurism is, in French, "le geste destructeur des anarchistes," in Italian, "il gesto distruttivo dei libertarî." In neither case is the translation "freedom-bringers," proposed by R. W. Flint in various English editions, accurate or acceptable.

[10] The emphasis placed upon the value (interessant) and freshness of the document, reserved for the readers of Le ro alone, suggests exclusivity inasmuch as the term primeur evokes produce that is harvested before its naturally occurring moment of ripeness and wines consumed immediately without undergoing even a modicum of aging (vins nouveaux). So, in spite of his caveats, Calmette is promising his upper and middle class readers a heady, volatile brew whose delivery has been rushed to market.

[11] Calmette assumes that the court of public opinion –or, at least, Le ro's bourgeois readership—will be composed not of "mediocre intellects" like those who rioted at the inaugural Turin performance of La donna è mobile, but of thoughtful and critical citizens. His readership will see beyond the manifesto's incendiary hype and attribute its hardiesse to the extravagant lyrical sensibilities of an artist endowed with an "aristocratic talent." Yet in the backdrop of the preface hovers the specter of a public sphere, that, instead of fulfilling the values of Enlightment reason, has the potential to become a theater where forms of irrationality regularly trump and triumph over critical reason: a theater of scandal and thrill like that enacted by the Foundation and Manifesto of Futurism itself.

Jeffrey T. Schnapp  

Jeffrey T. Schnapp holds the Rosina Pierotti Chair of Italian Studies at Stanford University where he co-directs the Stanford Humanities Lab (http://www.stanford.edu).

Notes

1. Le ro, February 20, 1909. Unless otherwise indicated, all translations into English are by the author.

2. Corriere della Sera, October 15, 1908.

3. The items in question were "A Plea for the Jews" (May 16, 1897), "M. Scheurer-Kestner' (Nov. 25, 1897), "The Syndicate" (Dec. 1, 1897), and "The Minutes" (Dec. 5, 1897); "J'accuse" came out in L'Aurore on Jan. 13, 1898 as an open letter to the French President Félix Faure. All are anthologized in Émile Zola, The Dreyfus Affair, J'accuse and Other Writings, ed. Alain Pagès, trans. Eleanor Levieux, (New Haven: Yale University Press, 1996).

Project MUSE Journals Volume 16, Number 2, April 2009 Total Theater and the Missing Pieces of the Brazilian Avant-Garde

Volume 16, Number 2, April 2009

E-ISSN: 1080-6601 Print ISSN: 1071-6068

DOI: 10.1353/mod.0.0092

Total Theater and the Missing Pieces of the Brazilian Avant-Garde
Sarah J. Townsend

In the fall of 1933, the avant-garde scene in São Paulo was abuzz with talk of the new Teatro da Experiência, trumpeted as the most radical theater experiment the country had yet seen. On the program for the inaugural event was O Homem e o Cavalo (Man and the Horse), a "Spectacle in Nine Tableaux" by the notorious poet, novelist, and provocateur Oswald de Andrade. It was an ambitious undertaking for a group of amateurs: the dramatic action ranged from St. Peter's pearly gates to a Soviet tribunal, while its huge cast of characters included Cleopatra, talking horses, Madame Jesus, the Voice of Stalin, Fu-Man-Chu, and a Poet-Soldier who casually announces Hitler's imminent genocide of the Jews. As fate would have it, the author failed to finish the script in time, and the theater opened instead with O Bailado do Deus Morto (Dance of the Dead God), a ritualistic performance piece composed by director Flávio de Carvalho and performed by a cast that included black actors and musicians. On 17 November 1933, the day after an entire battalion of police officers showed up uninvited for the third performance, the premises were shut down and placed under armed guard. The Teatro da Experiência became a mere anecdote in avant-garde lore, O Homem e o Cavalo never made its debut, and the might-have-been revolutionary masses never got their chance to witness the grand spectacle of world history on a small São Paulo stage.

What exactly did they miss? The eminent theater critic Sábato Magaldi echoed a sentiment shared by many latter-day critics and theater practitioners in Brazil when he wrote that O Homem e o Cavalo represented Oswald de Andrade's most ambitious attempt to create a kind of "total theater"—a visionary project that, "by virtue of being at the forefront of its era, doesn't even seem to belong to the reality of Brazilian theater."2 From the vantage point of the present, Oswald's drama appears to be the harbinger of a theatrical revolution that never happened, the missing piece of an avant-garde movement that shook the foundations of literature, music, art, and architecture but left the nineteenth-century stage intact. Magaldi and others insist that Oswald's unrealized plan for a "stadium theater" that would bridge the gap between art and action betrays many of the same aesthetic and political preoccupations as Max Reinhardt's expressionist experiments, Erwin Piscator's TotalTheater, and the constructivist montages of Vladimir Mayakovsky and Vsevolod Meyerhold. Invoking a discourse that remains endemic to critical accounts of the European and Euro-American avant-garde, they celebrate O Homem as a valiant effort to mobilize the masses by blending popular performance traditions with the erudite genres of the elite and opening up the hallowed halls of bourgeois theater to new artistic media such as film to create a performance that would be nothing less than "total."

In what follows, I reverse the terms of this interpretation by examining the elusive ideal of total theater through the optic of Oswald de Andrade's ill-fated spectacle and the events that led up to its non-performance. My reading situates O Homem e o Cavalo in the local and global political landscape of the 1930s, placing it at the juncture of a triangular relationship formed by the new media of mass culture, the expansion of the modern state, and the appearance of ideological rifts within a group of intellectuals who were identified as the artistic avant-garde. At the outset, it is important to clarify a point that discussions of total theater all too often obscure: not all totalities are alike. Indeed, I argue that in bringing the aesthetic paradigm of total theater head-to-head with a historical narrative of imperialism, O Homem e o Cavalo redeploys many of the formal processes associated with the avant-garde—the reconration of scenic space, abstraction, technological mediation—in order to posit a very different model of art and its relationship to political agency. One of my aims in this essay is to show how the representational dilemmas that anti-imperialist artists faced at this crucial historical juncture can illuminate the possibilities and potential pitfalls of current attempts to theorize the avant-garde as a "transnational" or "global" phenomenon; another is to demonstrate why the theater of the Brazilian avant-garde is a good place to begin such an endeavor, precisely because there is so little of it.

Total Theater, Mass Culture, and the Modern State

Few ideas are so closely tied to the vagaries and contradictions of European modernism as total theater and its more comprehensive cousin, the total work of art. In his insightful overview of the latter, Matthew Wilson Smith identifies the total work of art as a re for "un-reconciled dialectical struggles performed under the sign of aesthetic totality": struggles that involve art's relation to the emergence of mass culture, new technologies, and the expansive designs of the modern nation-state.3 Smith takes a long (and perhaps too totalizing) view of his subject, painting cyberspace as its new frontier while tracing its roots all the way back to Schiller's ideal of the aesthetic state, a utopian realm of beauty and culture in which social divisions can be imaginatively overcome by art. Like every other genealogy of the tradition, however, his revolves around Wagner's concept of the Gesamtkunstwerk, a performative synthesis of music, poetry, and dance in which each achieves its ultimate expression through the formation of an organic unity. Wagner's "theater of the future" evoked the public festivals that had propelled the movement for German unification in 1871 and reflected the convergence of nationalism and popular politics that George Mosse has referred to as the "nationalization of the masses."4 Man's mind, like the bourgeois public sphere, had been "fragmented" by the mechanization and commodification of modern life; Wagner's own art (liberated from the demands of the market by royal patronage) proposed to heal these rifts by crafting absorptive illusions through the use of elaborate stage mechanics, all carefully concealed so that "the public, that representation of daily life, forgets the confines of the auditorium, and lives and breathes now only in the artwork, which seems to it as Life itself, and on the stage, which seems the wide expanse of the whole World."5

Wagner's Gesamtkunstwerk cast a long shadow over the avant-gardes of the early twentieth century, and critics as well as later generations of artists who have claimed the vanguard legacy often use "total theater" as a rubric for a wide array of theatrical endeavors from this time: projects such as Antonin Artaud's metaphysical "theater of cruelty" and the Soviet Meyerhold's attempt to create an "October in the theater," both of which sought to break through the fourth wall by taking a page from commedia dell'arte and the circus, though each envisioned totality in different terms. The most explicit elaboration of a total theater ideal was the TotalTheater project developed during the late twenties in Weimar by the director Erwin Piscator and members of the Bauhaus school. The Bauhaus's emphasis on craft and design was a socialist-inspired attempt to wed functionalism and beauty, but it also gave the school a pipeline to industry and thus a degree of autonomy from unreliable state funding. Piscator's "proletarian theater" drew on elements of popular musical revues, the mass pageantry of early Soviet theater, and technological innovations including mobile footways and stages, loudspeakers, and film projections. A key component was the reconration of theatrical space: architect Walter Gropius drew up plans for a monumental hall for nearly two thousand spectators seated on movable blocks of chairs, an arrangement intended to facilitate performances that would spread throughout the entire auditorium and incorporate the spectators. Like its predecessor, this radicalized version of the Gesamtkunstwerk was conceived as an organic whole, though its constitutive elements were manifestly mechanical and the object of its impact was the intellect; according to Piscator, his goal was to "dematerialise the stage by means of a total technique, to make it a light and flexible instrument destined to serve mind and not sentimentality."6 Jeffrey T. Schnapp explains that for Piscator, "the revolution was embedded somewhere in the real itself. The theater's task was simply to strip away all externals and to place that rough and ready reality directly onstage." Totality, in other words, meant an immediately perceptible "totality of effect."7

The 1929 stock market crash put a halt to construction plans, and as the 1930s wore on TotalTheater became a fraught strategy for the Left. Even before Hitler became chancellor in 1933, the Nazis laid claim to the legacy of Wagner and the infrastructure of civic performance to develop their own mass rituals, open-air theaters, and choreographed parades—aspects of the "aestheticization of the political" that Walter Benjamin identified as the modus operandi of fascism. In his essay "Border Crossings: Italian/German Peregrinations of the Theater of Totality," Schnapp follows the TotalTheater model's migration to Fascist Italy, where it was embraced as kindred in spirit to Mussolini's proposed "theater of masses" and as theoretical confirmation of Futurist experiments as well as state-sponsored traveling pageants involving hundreds of performers and up to 15,000 spectators. His narrative ends in Rome in October 1934 at a conference held by the Italian Academy and attended by such diverse res as Edward Gordon Craig, Jacques Copeau, Alexander Tairov, Filippo Marinetti, W.B. Yeats, and the special guest, Walter Gropius himself, all speaking a shared language of total theatricality. Noting the "ideological drift and blurring" that facilitated surprising "cultural convergences" across national boundaries (BC, 83), Schnapp argues that artists on opposite sides of the political divide responded to a perceived crisis of bourgeois theater by creating new forms of mass spectacle that fueled what he calls a "modernist politics of immediacy" (BC, 89).

The Absence of a Brazilian Theatrical Avant-Garde

Schnapp attributes the search for "total" aesthetic solutions among revolutionaries of all stripes to a postwar milieu in which religion was on the wane and the new technologies of war and peace were calling humanist assumptions into question. And yet these phenomena were themselves bound up with a profound shift in the modes and mechanisms of global imperialism. Across the Atlantic and south of the equator in Brazil, debates over how to overturn the cultural legacy of colonialism drove the development of the avant-garde movement known as modernismo, which took shape during the Semana de Arte Moderna, a festival of art exhibitions, poetry readings, music recitals, and lectures held in São Paulo in February 1922. Although most modernistas came from the elite, they cultivated an interest in the cultures of their darker-skinned compatriots while giving an occasional nod to the vast numbers of Italian, German, and Japanese immigrants who were flocking to São Paulo during this period. It was Oswald de Andrade who invented modernismo's most enduring motif, the tonguein cheek inversion of European primitivism that has become the hallmark of a paradoxical Brazilian nationalism: cannibalism. In his 1928 "Anthropophagist Manifesto," he invoked the culinary rituals of the region's original inhabitants as a model of how Brazilians could critically digest their enemies' culture and escape the trap of cultural dependency and heralded the practice of eating the Other as both the sign of Brazilian difference and "the world's single law": "We want the Carib Revolution. Greater than the French Revolution. The unification of all productive revolts for the progress of humanity."8 Oswald played up the fact that Montaigne's "noble savage" was inspired by the egalitarian customs of Brazil's Tupinamba tribe and shrugged his shoulders at the more recent advances of European civilization, declaring, "we already had Com-munism. We already had surrealist language. The Golden Age."9

But Oswald was not the only modernista putting a new spin on the old ethnic standbys of nationalist iconography; his manifesto was a response to a rival group of modernistas known as the verde-amarelistas (an homage to the green and gold colors of the Brazilian flag) that openly advocated fascism. Because the majority of the masses and the historical origins of the nation were clearly not "white," the connections between race and fascist representation were rather different in Brazil than in Europe and relied on a strategy of symbolic inclusion coupled with social exclusion. Members immersed themselves in indigenous mythology and sought to declare Tupi the national language, even as they argued that the destiny of the indigenous race was to disappear and leave nothing but "spirit"—i.e., culture—behind.10 These fractures in the avant-garde front turned into open rifts following the crisis provoked by the 1929 stock market crash and the subsequent Revolution of 1930, which overthrew the weak central regime and set the stage for the rise of Getúlio Vargas, a re whose legacy continues to loom large over the country's political scene. Brazil's "Father of the Poor" was a populist of sorts: his government granted women's suffrage, instituted retirement pensions for workers, and consolidated federal control over the regional oligarchies that had run the show during the Old Republic (1889–1930); he also beefed up the military, subordinated unions to the authority of the state, and endorsed the torture of political opponents by the secret police. In 1932, the São Paulo elite led a three-month "Constitutionalist Revolution" in an attempt to regain the privileges they had enjoyed under the liberal oligarchic regime; in military terms they failed, but the upshot was a détente and eventual alliance between Vargas and the old elite, leading to a new constitution in 1934 that consecrated him as the legitimate executive. Legal order, however, would prove to be short-lived: in 1935, following a failed "communist conspiracy," the State suspended civil liberties and ordered thousands of arrests that dealt a crippling blow to the Left; in 1937, Vargas abandoned democratic pretenses and declared the Estado Novo, a corporatist dictatorship that lasted until shortly after World War II.11

More than five decades after his second stint in power ended with his suicide in the face of a military coup, Vargas continues to be an object of collective ambivalence and even affection, in no small part because his regime is closely linked to the genesis of cultural icons and repertoires that still set the parameters of national identity today. It was during the 1930s that the notion of Brazil as a "racial democracy" began to take shape; it was also the era when soccer, once the preserve of the elite, became a popular obsession while racially coded genres such as samba shed their stigma to become transnational commodities and emblems of national identity. As the historian Daryle Williams has underlined, the state did not initiate these complex processes, nor did it attain the degree of control that some of its ideological cousins in Europe enjoyed; instead, the administration's strategy was to "ma(k)e cultural management its official business" by creating an extensive network of patronage in order to bring artists and intellectuals under the purview of the state.12 In 1933, the federal government became the official sponsor of Rio's annual Carnival parade. In the increasingly important arena of radio—in which the state's ability to intervene was constrained by limited resources and the interests of foreign capital—it crafted corporate-friendly legislation while requiring stations to broadcast official propaganda and devote a large percentage of programming to "national" themes. But it was modernismo whose fortunes underwent the most drastic shift under the "revolutionary" state. The verdeamarelista Plínio Salgado, who founded the fascist Integralist party in 1932, was not the only one to benefit from the new political conration; modernistas of all political stripes were given positions in the new Ministry of Education, while government agencies generated outwardly apolitical, "cultural" journals that succeeded in drawing in writers who had long lamented the dearth of forums for their work. In a speech delivered in 1951, Vargas aptly summed up the avant-garde myth his own government had helped create, claiming that "the collective forces that provoked the revolutionary modernist movement in Brazilian literature . . . were the same ones that precipitated the victorious Revolution of 1930 in the social and political field."13 The state recast modernismo's experimental ethic as an authentic expression of the popular and prescient precursor to political change, even as it circumscribed it to the realm of "literature" in order to harness its iconoclastic edge.

When the modernistas parted ways, Oswald de Andrade veered to the left and, in 1931, began a fraught relationship with the Brazilian Communist Party, which had been founded in 1922—the same year as the Week of Modern Art. The erstwhile dandy bid a public adieu to his former cohorts in the preface to his experimental novel Serafim Ponte Grande, completed in 1928 but left unpublished until 1933. In the brief text, he lambastes modernista bohemians for masquerading as agents of social revolution, recalling that in the heady environment of the 1920s, "the modernist movement, culminating in the anthropophagic plague, seemed to indicate an advanced phenomenon . . . It even looked like the coffee boom might set the semicolony's nouveau riche literature on a level with costly imperialistic surrealisms."14 Those illusions crumbled in the face of the economic crisis, "just as almost all Brazilian 'vanguardist' literature crumbled, being provincial and suspect if not extremely impoverished and reactionary" (SGP, 5). It was a harsh judgment, one that the writer would later qualify. Yet it was not a rejection of stylistic experimentation as such. Rather, Oswald's critique takes aim at what Frankfurt philosopher Herbert Marcuse would refer to only a few years later as the "affirmative" nature of bourgeois culture, which may entertain the possibility of an alternative to the existing order but ultimately legitimates the status quo by offering "spiritual" progress and "ethical" freedom as consolation for oppression and material lack.15 The author derides his own novel for proposing the facile solution of "transnational nudism" to the structural inequalities produced by economic imperialism and announces that, having tired of being an "upper-class clown," he will henceforth aspire to be, "if nothing else, a circus roustabout in the Proletarian Revolution"16—a kind of stagehand, in other words, who would rearrange the set and fashion props to facilitate the working class in performing its own creative feats in the political ring.

As was true of other Latin American avant-gardists during the 1930s, Oswald's political radicalization did in fact prompt a turn to theater. In an article published in 1935 and subsequently adopted as the preface to a second edition, the author explains that O Homem e o Cavalo, his first full-length play in Portuguese, "is a piece of high fantasy in which I place man in the transition—between the war horse and the turf horse (bourgeois society) and horsepower (socialist society)." As such, it "is a book that is of interest to the masses," though the limited print run effectively circumscribed its audience to a small group of intellectuals.17O Rei da Vela and A Morta met a similar fate. It was not until 1967, under another "modernizing dictatorship," that a landmark staging of O Rei da Vela would help give birth to the counterculture movement known as Tropicália.18 Teatro Oficina's controversial production pioneered an Artaud-inspired "theater of aggression" while establishing Oswald's reputation as a visionary playwright who, as one of the actors wrote, "opens a path toward a national theater, a total theater, which is only now properly understood."19 More recently, the director José Celso has sought to build a stadium theater that would provide a proper stage for O Homem—a play he describes as the "total surmounting" of Russian constructivism "blended with the Great Rituals that shape the Brazilian Mixed Races culture."20 In 2003, after years ting a local developer, Celso announced a deal: the developers would build their mall, but alongside it they would construct a 1,000-seat theater inspired by Walter Gropius's design for the TotalTheater in Weimar, complete with a ceiling made of retractable movie screens that opened up to the tropical sky. Like its forebear, this project has since fallen through.

But on what grounds is Oswald's theater identified as the missing piece of a national avant-garde? The justification for such claims does not lie in detailed analyses of the texts or the events surrounding their non-performance, of which there are surprisingly few—or perhaps not so surprising, given that total theater aims to render both text and stage obsolete. Instead, most artists and critics who advocate this interpretation do so on the basis of Oswald's "Do Teatro, Que É Bom," a humorous dialogue published in a daily newspaper in 1943. The dialogue begins with an unnamed speaker's defense of an amateur group engaged in what his partner derisively refers to as "chamber theater." Speaker number one insists that such efforts should be applauded, if for no other reason than that "they give us a break from the cinema, that growing stupidification by means of the screen with which the United States flooded the world in order to take it over without resistance." Voicing an Adorno-esque critique of the culture industry, he scoffs that "when they spoke against the opium of the people, they should have made it plural and added cinema and soccer."21 His interlocutor, however, takes issue with this extrapolation from Marx and contends that what is needed is a "theater of shock," a "stadium theater" that, along with the radio, the sports arena, and the silver screen, will educate and entertain the growing masses. Tracing the history of theater from its inception in ancient Greece, he claims that in the nineteenth century, with the rise of bourgeois individualism, what was lost was "the religious character of the theater, the collective festival, festival of the masses, festival of the people" (DT, 90). His list of exemplary res includes Ibsen, Jarry, Cocteau, and in particular Meyerhold, whose "ethic of spectacle" is lauded as the pinnacle of modern theater. This leads into a discussion of "the war-like image of fascism" cultivated by the acolytes of Stalin and "the petty-bourgeoisie of Mussolini, nursed by bureaucracy and the confessional, wanting to live dangerously in a sensational release of inhibitions" (91–92). His proposed antidote to this attack on the "Hegelian progression of the spirit" is not primarily a playwright (though Oswald may have in mind his famous Pageant of the Paterson Strike): it is the journalist and globetrotting radical John Reed. The text concludes with the first speaker, who has long since tempered his enthusiastic embrace of chamber theater, declaring that "John Reed's soldier fulfilled his mission on the living stage of contemporary history" . Art and history merge, on-stage and off-stage become one, and thesis and antithesis are resolved in the total transformation of reality.

Or are they? The dialogue's self-mocking tone calls into question the ease with which the final synthesis is achieved, while the references to contemporary political realities hint at a more serious subtext: Oswald, always unorthodox, had distanced himself from the Communist Party by this time and would break away two years later, in 1945; Stalin, denounced in the dialogue as a "villain," had executed Meyerhold three years earlier for his refusal to tow the social realist line; in Brazil, meanwhile, Getúlio Vargas was paying popular musicians to sing his praises. The use of the dialogue form is significant, then, because it enacts an unresolved debate in leftist circles and indicates that the outcome is not a done deal. At one point, for instance, the speaker who sings the praises of "chamber theater" points to advances in stage design and cites the work of the French director Louis Jouvet, who spent the early forties in exile in Brazil; calling it an "admirable reaction against the corruption brought about by the cinema," he explains that "sensing itself under attack, the theater improved," producing intimate theaters that provided a refuge for "the spirit of that fabulous Paris, which that forest ranger Hitler's filthy boot is unsuccessfully trying to crush." Rather than refuting this implicit equation of mass culture with fascism, his partner brings up Meyerhold and a long list of earlier playwrights-of-the-people, ending with the comment that "one day, perhaps soon, we may be able to add, in an honest sense, Wagner and Oberammergau . . ." (DT, 87). The argument for the revolutionary nature of mass theater thus leads to two disturbing counter-examples that signal its potential as a vehicle for reaction: a composer celebrated by the Nazis as an icon of German nationalism, and a Bavarian village famous for its centuries-long tradition of a massive, day-long Passion Play—famous, too, for the anti-Semitic nature of the pageant and Hitler's ringing endorsement of it.22

Only by turning a blind eye to these apparent impasses that trail off into ellipses is it possible to read this pseudo-Platonic dialogue as a programmatic manifesto for total theater; its relation to O Homem e o Cavalo becomes even more complex when one realizes that "O Teatro" was written nearly a decade later, at a time when, after several frustrated attempts to stage his own plays, Oswald was no longer writing theater at all. Even if we take the advocate of stadium theater to be the unequivocal mouthpiece for the author, his pedagogical injunction to "educate the world" is light years away from the contumacious circus laborer of the Serafim preface. The two speakers define their framework as international, but the specter of the nation is impossible to escape because a stumbling block stands in the way of the dialectic's progression: not just the historic wax and wane of fascism, but the concurrent rise and reification of Brazil's own corporatist state.

Historians and sociologists have been drawing attention to the political and institutional shifts that fostered the flowering of the Brazilian avant-garde for several decades now. But this knowledge in itself is not a sufficient solution to the methodological problem of how to interpret modernismo's formal innovations, nor is the recent turn toward "transnationalism" a quick fix to the nation-state's hold over culture, as evidenced by Fernando J. Rosenberg's recent study Geopolitics and the Latin American Avant-Garde. The book makes the claim that whereas the European avant-gardes simply rered imperialist assumptions, their Latin American counterparts "explored the limits of a national, culturalist response to crisis of the universality of civilization" by creating "narratives of space" that undermined the linear narrative of progress.23 The author explicitly endorses this practice of "embodied universality" as a model for dealing with the cultural politics of our own age—a disturbing suggestion given that he avoids any discussion of Latin American avant-gardists who espoused fascism, dismisses any overtly polemical work as a "repression of critical consciousness," and devotes two chapters to the Brazilian modernista Mário de Andrade without noting that some of the writer's most exemplary work was facilitated by his position as a cultural administrator under Vargas.24 This kind of affirmative criticism replicates the very dynamic at work in the institutionalization of Brazilian modernismo: it redefines "politics" as an ethico-aesthetic category and delegitimizes political engagement, privileging a specifically literary form of "cosmopolitanism" that was canonized by a politically repressive, nationalist regime. Such analyses might broaden their geographical scope, but their critique is a red herring because they define cultural nationalism as a particular style that can be (un)written on the page.

Rosenberg's recognition of space as a critical category in the study of the avant-gardes is on point. Yet if he, like most critics of the Latin American vanguardias, bypasses a discussion of theater, perhaps it is because solutions crafted within the closed confines of poetic or narrative space don't always hold up when space becomes something more than metaphorical and actual bodies are involved. Although no genre or medium is immune from the sort of disciplinary operation that abstracts an artistic object from the process of its production in order to craft the illusion of absolute autonomy, theater tends to present greater obstacles to redemptive modes of interpretation that attribute a progressive function to works of art on the sole basis of their symbolic representation of social relations. Because it requires the presence of a collective audience, as well as a social and material space in which to perform, theater's autonomy from the existing socio-political order is always, in the words of Loren Kruger, manifestly "impure." It is for this reason, Kruger argues, that theater is often a key site of struggle among competing attempts to define the proper articulation of art and society. She concludes: "At once more and less than art, theater straddles the disputed border country between the aesthetic state and the political and provides the stage on which the contradiction between them can be enacted."25

The tenuous nature of theatrical representation may be one reason why the Vargas government chose not to subsidize the dramatic arts for most of the 1930s, while it was still battling open opposition from the oligarchic elites and consolidating control over the fractious urban labor sector. As in Germany and Italy, regional divisions ran deep and there was little historical precedent for a strong central government; Brazil, however, was on the receiving end of the mass exodus of immigrants that allowed many European nations to externalize evidence of capitalism's growing contradictions. The origin myths that underpinned the aesthetic politics of Europe's fascist regimes also had a more precarious foundation in a country whose historical roots lay in colonialism. In 1888, Brazil had become the last country in the world to abolish African slavery; less than fifty years later, the country's new ruling forces were attempting to redefine race as an axis of national unity. The notion of a shared "Brazilian" culture, in other words, was a fragile fiction that threatened to collapse in the theater, where the gap between the real and the ideal was marked by the presence of the stage.

Perhaps this is why the police felt it necessary to make such an extravagant display of force in shutting down a small theater like the Teatro da Experiência. The space in which Man and the Horse was to have had its debut was a far cry from the grandiose, stadium-like structures that Gropius planned for the TotalTheater project; it had a relatively modest number of seats (around 275) and was housed in the basement of the Clube de Artistas Modernos (CAM), a social club founded in November 1932 by Antônio Gomide, Carlos Prado, Emiliano di Cavalcanti, and Flávio de Carvalho, a group of "modern artists" dedicated to defending what they called "the interests of the class."26 Teatro da Experiência was the brainchild of Carvalho, a wayward scion of the local aristocracy who was an architect, visual artist, and early performance artist of sorts.27 Much like Piscator, Carvalho conceived of his Teatro as a "laboratory" that would "function with the impartial spirit of laboratory research"; as he explained it in his application for a permit, the purpose was to explore "the world of ideas" by experimenting with "settings, modes of diction, mimesis, the dramatization of new elements of expression, problems of lighting and sound, conjugated to the movement of abstract forms," all in order "to form a practical base for the psychology of entertainment."28

Such a proposal might have aroused little suspicion at some other time or in some other place. But as it happened, the Teatro opened its doors toward the end of a pivotal year in the course of modern history. In Brazil, 1933 was dominated by the lengthy lead-up to the inauguration of a Constituent National Assembly that would draft a constitution and return the country to legal rule even as it paved the way for the authoritarian Estado Novo by legitimating Vargas's power. The Assembly's inauguration fell on 15 November—the very same day that Carvalho's O Bailado do Deus Morto made its debut.29 Meanwhile in Germany, Hitler became chancellor on 30 January 1933, the Reichstag burned on 27 February and by the end of March the legislature had granted the federal government dictatorial powers; in July, Trotsky pointed to the German Communist Party's rapid disintegration as an indication that Stalin's "bureaucratic centrism" had reached a point at which the Left opposition had no choice but to break from the Comintern. Japan unleashed its imperial ambitions in Manchuria while Franklin Roosevelt spelled out the New Deal and Good Neighbor policy in his 4 March radio address, signalling a shift (in theory) away from armed intervention into Latin American affairs toward economic penetration and an intense campaign of cultural propaganda.

These distant events all resonated loudly within the small artists' club out of which Carvalho's theatrical "experience" emerged. One of the most frequent performers at the Clube dos Artistas Modernos was Elsie Houston, a classically trained "mulatta" soprano who would later gain fame in the nightclubs of New York City for a repertoire featuring what the press referred to as Afro-Brazilian "voodoo songs"; she was also the wife of the French surrealist Benjamin Péret, who had recently been expelled from Brazil for his Trotskyist activities. In June of 1933, CAM held an exhibition of paintings and lithographs by the German Käthe Kollwitz, which opened with a lecture by the prominent Trotskyist and art critic Mário Pedrosa, who had studied in Berlin and fought in early street battles against the Nazis ( 1). In July, the club unveiled an exhibition of Soviet poster art brought back from Russia by the modernista painter Tarsila do Amaral, drawing considerable attention from the press. And yet nothing could top the talk by Caio Prado Junior, a rising star in the Brazilian Communist Party whose landmark Evolução Política do Brasil appeared this same year. Prado Junior's presentation on his recent trip to Russia drew six hundred people to CAM one evening in September; loudspeakers were placed outside so that the long line of people who were unable to squeeze into the hall could hear his favorable account of the new Soviet society as well as the debate that ensued. Other events included lectures on subjects ranging from modern China to "Brazilian folklore" and the Ingay Amazonians; a demonstration of Japanese dances; and a talk by David Alfaro Siqueiros, the Mexican muralist who would attempt to assassinate Trotsky in 1940.30

What the countless newspaper articles that document the development of the Clube dos Artistas Modernos and the Teatro da Experiência's debut do not always reveal is who attended these events. For this, one has to turn to the archive of the Delegacia Estadual de Ordem Política e Social (DEOPS), Brazil's notorious political police. The DEOPS opened a file on the club in July of 1933 and assigned the task of surveillance to an informant identified by the code name "Guarany." The agent's reports offer intriguing glimpses into a unique and ultimately ephemeral milieu where left-leaning artists, anarchists, Trotskyists, Communist Party faithfuls, and those who refused to be pigeonholed into any one of the left's proliferating factions formed contingent alliances and often engaged in tense disputes. One such re was Oreste Ristori, an old timer from the heyday of anarco-syndicalism who had acquired quasi-mythic stature after being kicked out of his native Italy and Argentina before arriving in Brazil ( 2). In a defiantly detailed declaration Ristori gave to the police a few years later before being deported to Italy, where he would be shot by the German army during World War II for his role in the antifascist resistance, he stated that he had begun frequenting the Clube dos Artistas Modernos because he "had the desire to meet various [diversos] intellectuals."31 He was not the only one. Throughout the file on CAM, the club's unknown mole voices concern about the intermingling of intellectuals and "foreign

Oreste Ristori, an Italian labor agitator who regularly attended the Club dos Artistas Modernos, in an arrest photo from 1935. File 364, archive of the Delegacia Estadual de Ordem Política e Social (DEOPS). Courtesy of the Arquivo Público do Estado de São Paulo, São Paulo, Brazil.

workers," as in a document dated 29 November in which he notes that the evening's meeting was attended by large numbers of people from Belém and Bom Retiro—two of São Paulo's largest working-class neighborhoods, where Italian immigrants had recently been joined by an influx of Eastern European Jews.32 A report on Tarsila do Amaral's discussion of proletarian art ominously warns that the audience "was almost entirely composed of individuals wearing collar-less shirts and red ties, with the air of terrorists and undesirables, the majority of them made up of foreigners." And what had they come to hear? Guarany denounces Tarsila's "disguised agitation of praise for militant communism," but he declines to go into detail. Rather, he sums up her speech with a phrase that is repeated like a litany throughout all his reports: "It has nothing to do with art."33 ( 3)

In his account of the club's activities (written after the declaration of the Estado Novo), Carvalho echoed his unidentified observer's remarks, taking pains to state his disapproval of the "extreme leftist elements, some having nothing to do with art" that "infiltrated" the club and allowed political passions to overwhelm the pursuit of rational beauty.34 And yet it was his theater that led to the club's downfall—perhaps because its "entertainment" appeal threatened to bring yet another element into this already suspect mix. Carvalho's main collaborator on O Bailado do Deus Morto was Henrique Costa (Henricão), a black chauffeur who would become a successful samba composer; Costa composed the music and performed in the piece, which drew a "diverse" crowd with twice as many spectators as there were seats. Its success helps explain the authorities' insistence that not just O Bailado but the theater itself constituted a "Communist" threat—indeed, the script contains a few risqué references to the anatomy of a primitive god, but it remains resolutely abstract and it is impossible to discern any direct allusions to contemporary events. Race was never explicitly mentioned as a cause, of course, because the state's ideological project depended on disavowing the political dimension of skin color even as it celebrated blackness as an integral element of national culture. In such a context, the likely mix of people in the audience and the presence of black actors on an experimental stage where generic conventions were less fixed would have raised a red flag.35 (. 4 and 5)

A few days after the long arm of the law put an end to the fun, as the police perused scripts of the Teatro's forthcoming works (including his own) and deliberated on its ultimate fate, Oswald gave a reading of scenes from O Homem e o Cavalo upstairs in the club. In an article announcing the event he expressed confidence that the theater would prevail and spoke of plans to stage his own play. His optimism turned out to be misplaced: the case went to court, where a judge affiliated with the Integralists decided in favor of the police, provoking an outcry from prominent intellectuals as far away as Buenos Aires and a fiery speech in the national constituent assembly by an opposition delegate who decried the suppression of a valiant attempt to form a "completely independent theater."36 The club quickly lost members and closed soon after, leaving a would-be audience to speculate as to what O Homem might have looked like onstage. "The Teatro da Experiência's task is going to be enormous," Oswald had said, because it would be "attempting to reduce, for a stage four meters in size (doubled in the auditorium, it's true), a play for a stadium or the cinema, with forty-five characters, a dog, and a horse."37
